description: From Middle English fat, from Old English fǣtt (“fatted, fat”), from Proto-West Germanic *faitid (“fatted”), originally the past participle of the verb *faitijan (“to make fat”), from *fait (“fat”).

entries.meaning: Carrying more fat than usual on one's body; plump; not lean or thin.
examples: The fat man had trouble getting through the door.
The fattest pig should yield the most meat.

entries.meaning: Thick; large.
examples: The fat wallets of the men from the city brought joy to the peddlers.

entries.meaning: Bulbous; rotund.
examples: So this was my future home, I thought!  […]  Backed by towering hills, the but faintly discernible purple line of the French boundary off to the southwest, a sky of palest Gobelin flecked with fat, fleecy little clouds, it in truth looked a dear little city; the city of one's dreams.

entries.meaning: Bountiful.
Oily; greasy; unctuous; rich (said of food).
(obsolete) Exhibiting the qualities of a fat animal; coarse; heavy; gross; dull; stupid.
examples: making our western wits fat & mean

entries.meaning: Fertile; productive.
examples: a fat soil; a fat pasture

entries.meaning: Rich; producing a large income; desirable.
examples: a fat benefice; a fat office;  a fat job

entries.meaning: Abounding in riches; affluent; fortunate.
examples: persons grown fat and wealthy by a long and successful imposture

entries.meaning: (dated, printing) Of a character which enables the compositor to make large wages; said of matter containing blank, cuts, or many leads, etc.
examples: a fat take; a fat page

entries.meaning: (golf) Being a shot in which the ground is struck before the ball.
examples: Hitting a thin shot from a fairway bunker is more productive than hitting a fat shot.

entries.meaning: (theater) Of a role: significant; major; meaty.
examples: He is what the theatre calls a “fat” role — a man suddenly confronted by a terrible duty. He is called upon to revenge the murder of his father and to right a wrong against the state.

entries.meaning: Alternative form of phat
examples: This isn't a place to talk about “hitting the decks” and making “fat beats”—you're not selling to an industry peer.

definitionGroups.group: (uncountable) A specialized animal tissue with high lipid content, used for long-term storage of energy: fat tissue.

entries.meaning: Such tissue as food: the fatty portion of (or trimmings from) meat cuts.
examples: Ask the butcher for a few pounds of fat for our greens.

entries.meaning: (countable) A lipid that is solid at room temperature, which fat tissue contains and which is also found in the blood circulation; sometimes, a refined substance chemically resembling such naturally occurring lipids.
examples: Dietary fat is not the evil that it was once misapprehended to be; carbs are increasingly recognized as a bigger driver of atherosclerosis via chronic insulin resistance and the vascular processes that cascade from it.

entries.meaning: That part of an organization deemed wasteful.
examples: We need to trim the fat in this company

entries.meaning: (slang) An erection.
examples: I saw Daniel crack a fat.

entries.meaning: (golf) A poorly played shot where the ball is struck by the top part of the club head. (see also thin, shank, toe)
The best or richest productions; the best part.
examples: to live on the fat of the land

entries.meaning: (dated, printing) Work containing much blank, or its equivalent, and therefore profitable to the compositor.
(informal, derogatory) A fat person.
examples: Prefer military, bodybuilders, jocks. No smokers or fats please.

entries.meaning: A beef cattle fattened for sale.

verbs.description: fat (third-person singular simple present fats, present participle fatting, simple past and past participle fatted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To make fat; to fatten.
examples: kill the fatted calf

entries.meaning: (intransitive, archaic) To become fat; to fatten.
(transitive, golf) To hit (a golf ball) with a fat shot.

description: From Middle English fat, from Old English fæt (“vat, vessel, jar, cup, casket, division”), from Proto-Germanic *fatą (“vessel”), from Proto-Indo-European *pod- (“vessel”). Cognate with Dutch vat (“barrel, vessel”), German Fass (“barrel, drum”), Swedish fat (“barrel, dish, cask”). See vat.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A large tub or vessel for water, wine, or other liquids; a cistern.
examples: In 1431 New College purchases brewing vessels, under the names of a mash fat, for 6s. 10d., a wort fat for 2s., a 'Gilleding' tub for 2s. 6d., and two tunning barrels at 8d. each, a leaden boiler for 24s., another for 12s., and a great copper beer pot for 13s. 4d.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A dry measure, generally equal to nine bushels.
